children.name: needing a lot of skill, hard work, and determination
challenging b1
children.definition: challenging/ˈtʃælɪndʒɪŋ, ˈtʃæləndʒɪŋ/  a challengingjoboractivityneeds a lot of hard work and skill, but it is also interesting and enjoyable:
examples: đầy thử thách
▪ the job wasn’t challenging enough for me - i wanted something more creative.
công việc chưa đủ thử thách đối với tôi- tôi muốn cái gì đó sáng tạo hơn.
▪ bowden called the piece ‘one of the most challenging pieces of music i’ve ever played'.
bowden gọi đó là 'một trong những bản nhạc khó nhất tôi từng chơi'.

children.name: be a challenge b1
children.definition: be a challenge/biː ə ˈtʃælɪndʒ/  if a newjoboractivityis a challenge, it is difficult, but you are determined to do it because it is interesting and exciting:
examples: là một thử thách
▪ you may find your first couple of months in the job quite a challenge.
mấy tháng đầu bạn có thể sẽ thấy công việc là một thử thách.
▪ getting the two groups to work together was a challenge, but we did it.
giúp hai nhóm hợp tác với nhau là một thử thách, nhưng chúng ta đã làm được.

children.name: demanding b1
children.definition: demanding/dɪˈmɑːndɪŋǁdɪˈmæn-/  a demandingjoboractivityis very difficult and tiring, because it needs all your effort and skill:
examples: đòi hỏi khắt khe
▪ being a nurse in a busy hospital is a demanding job - you don’t get much free time.
làm y tá ở một bệnh viện bận rộn là một công việc đòi hỏi khắt khe- bạn không có nhiều thời gian rỗi.

children.name: daunting x
children.definition: daunting/ˈdɔːntɪŋ/  if something is daunting, it seems almost impossible, and the idea of doing it makes you feel nervous:
examples: làm nản chí
▪ climbing everest is a daunting challenge for any mountaineer.
trèo lên đỉnh everest là một thử thách dễ nản lòng đối với bất kỳ tay leo núi nào.
daunting task
nhiệm vụ khó khăn
▪ i was faced with the daunting task of learning the whole script in 24 hours.
tôi gặp một nhiệm vụ khó khăn là phải học toàn bộ lời thoại trong 24 giờ.

children.name: take some doing x
children.definition: take some doing/ˌteɪk sʌm ˈduːɪŋ/  spoken use this about something that needs a lot of effort, skill, or determination, and you admire someone who does it:
examples: rất vất vả, mất nhiều công sức
▪ winning 3 gold medals in the olympic games takes some doing.
thắng 3 huy chương vàng thế vận hôi olympic phải mất nhiều công sức.
▪ it took some doing, but i finally persuaded jim to give me a few more days off.
dù mất nhiều công sức, nhưng cuối cùng tôi cũng thuyết phục được jim cho tôi nghỉ thêm vài ngày.

children.name: taxing x
children.definition: taxing/ˈtæksɪŋ/  formal difficult for someone because of needing more mental or physical effort than they are able to give:
examples: vất vả
▪ the job was taxing, but there were some good moments.
công việc vất vả, nhưng cũng có những khoảnh khắc đẹp.
▪ later in the pregnancy when the drive to work was getting too taxing, i worked at home two days a week.
giai đoạn mang thai sau này vì việc lái xe đi làm trở nên vất vả, tôi xin làm tại nhà hai ngày một tuần.

children.name: exacting x
children.definition: exacting/ɪgˈzæktɪŋ/  needing hard work and a lot of attention given to the details of a job, in order to make sure that it is done well:
examples: đòi hỏi chính xác cao
▪ film-editing is a difficult and exacting job.
biên tập phim là một công việc khó khăn và đòi hỏi sự chính xác.
▪ the article is based on the institute’s exacting study of wages in the health care professions.
bài báo dựa trên những nghiên cứu chính xác về lương bổng của những ngành nghề chăm sóc sức khỏe.

children.name: stretch x
children.definition: stretch/stretʃ/  if an activity, job etc stretches you, it is difficult enough to make you use all your skill, ability etc, and this helps you become better at it:tăng cường, mở rộng
examples: ▪ the exercises are designed to stretch the abilities of even the most advanced students.
▪ i was disappointed with the course -- i didn’t feel i was being stretched enough.

children.name: a situation that is difficult to deal with or talk about
difficult a1
children.definition: difficult/ˈdɪfɪkəlt/  a difficult situation or subject is not easy to deal with or talk about, and it makes you feel nervous or unhappy:
examples: ▪ things at home have been very difficult since my father died.
mọi việc ở nhà trở nên rất khó khăn từ khi cha tôi mất.
be in a difficult positionto have problems that are difficult to deal with :
▪ officials say they are in the difficult position of having to implement a law they strongly disagree with.
các viên chức nói họ đang trong tình thế khó khăn là phải bổ sung điều luật mà họ đã kịch liệt phản đối.

children.name: awkward b2
children.definition: awkward/ˈɔːkwəʳd/  an awkward situation or subject is difficult to deal with or talk about, especially because it might be embarrassing:
examples: khó khăn, khó xử
▪ he’s at an age when kids start asking awkward questions - like ‘where do babies come from?’
nó đang trong độ tuổi mà con nít bắt đầu hỏi những câu khó như ' em bé đến từ đâu?'

children.name: tricky b2
children.definition: tricky/ˈtrɪki/  a tricky situation is one that you have to deal with very carefully, because there are a lot of things that could easily go wrong:
examples: khó khăn, đòi hỏi sự khéo léo
▪ teachers often have to deal with tricky situations such as interviews with angry parents.
giáo viên thường xuyên phải đối phó với những tình huống khó khăn như phỏng vấn với những phụ huynh nóng tính.
it could/ would be tricky to do something
sẽ khó để làm gì
▪ it would be very tricky to try to stabilize the region without the support of other countries.
sẽ khó để ổn định khu vực mà không có sự ủng hộ của các nước khác.

children.name: delicate c1
children.definition: delicate/ˈdelɪkɪt, ˈdelɪkət/  a delicate matter, subject, situation etc is one that you must be very careful talking about or dealing with because you risk offending or upsetting people:
examples: tế nhị
▪ i am seeking your professional advice on a very delicate matter.
▪ madeline was wondering how to approach the delicate question of her salary with her new boss.

children.name: sensitive b2
children.definition: sensitive/ˈsensɪtɪv, ˈsensətɪv/  something that is sensitive, such as a political or social problem or a document, is likely to cause trouble or be likely to upset someone:
examples: nhạy cảm
▪ the team is gathering information on the sensitive subject of child abuse.
cả nhóm đang thu thập thông tin về những chủ đề nhạy cảm là lạm dụng trẻ em.
▪ the administration claims that the documents contain information of a highly sensitive political nature.
quản trị viên nói rằng hồ sơ có chứa thông tin về các quan điểm chính trị cực kỳ nhạy cảm

children.name: touchy x
children.definition: touchy a touchy subject or situation is one that you must be very careful talking about or dealing with because you risk upsetting or offending someone:tế nhị, nhạy cảm
examples: until now both candidates have avoided talking about the touchy subject of health care reform.

children.name: hot potato x
children.definition: hot potato informal a political problem that is very difficult for the government to deal with because there is a lot of disagreement about it:vấn đề có thể gây tranh cãi
examples: fortunately for the government, this issue has drawn attention away from the hot potato of funding the london underground.

children.name: to have problems when doing sth
have difficulty b1
children.definition: have difficulty/troubleb1 if you have difficulty when you are trying to do something, you cannot easily do it:
examples: have difficulty/ trouble (in) doing sth
▪ it was obvious the patient was having great difficulty breathing.
have difficulty/ trouble with sth
▪ a lot of japanese students of english have trouble with the pronunciation of ‘b’s and ’v’s.

children.name: find sth difficult a1
children.definition: findsomethingdifficult/ˌfaɪnd something ˈdɪfɪkəlt/  to not be able to do something easily, especially because you do not have enoughabilityorskill:
examples: thấy cái gì khó
▪ i found the course difficult at first, but it gradually got easier.
lúc đầu tôi thấy khóa học khó, nhưng về sau thì dễ hơn.
find it difficult to do something
thấy khó để làm gì
▪she always found it difficult to keep up with the rest of the class.
cô ấy luôn cảm thấy khó theo kịp cả lớp.

children.name: with difficulty b1
children.definition: with difficulty if you do sth with difficulty, you can do it, but only by using all your strength, all your determination etc:
examples: she spoke with difficulty, choking back her tears.

children.name: have a hard time u
children.definition: have a hard time to find it difficult to do sth, especially because there areunexpectedproblems or because you have difficultypersuadingother people:
examples: i tried to find the house but i had such a hard time, i decided to give up.
have a hard time doing sth
i’m still having a hard time getting the company to pay me.

children.name: can hardly b1
children.definition: can hardly/ barely/kən ˈhɑːʳdli, ˈbeəʳli/ if you can hardly or can barely do something, especially something physical, it is so difficult that you almost cannot do it:
examples: hầu như không thể
▪ by the end of the day she could hardly walk.
sau cùng thì cô ấy hầu như không thể đi lại.
▪ the smell was so bad that i could barely force myself to stay in the room.
mùi thơm đến mức tôi không thể ở yên trong phòng được.

children.name: have a job doing sth u
children.definition: have a job doing sth british spoken if you have a job doing something, it takes a lot of time or a lot of effort, and you may not be able to do it:
examples: ▪ you’ll have a job persuading him to give you any more money.
▪ there was some kind of festival going on, and we had a job finding somewhere to park the car.

children.name: too much u
children.definition: be too much for somebody/bi tuː ˈmʌtʃ fəʳ somebody/  if a situation or job is too much for someone, it is too difficult for them to deal with:
examples: quá khó đối với ai
▪ all the bullying and back-stabbing in the office was simply too much for him.
tất cả những lần bắt nạt và nói xấu chốn văn phòng chỉ đơn giản là quá khó khăn đối với anh ta.
▪ the job was too much for any single manager to cope with.
công việc quá khó cho bất kỳ người quản lý nào có thể giải quyết.

children.name: be a struggle b2
children.definition: be a struggle/biː ə ˈstrʌgəl/ if something is a struggle you have to try very hard and even suffer in order to do it:
examples: ▪ clark lived 112 days on the artificial heart, and each day was a struggle.
▪ she managed to get her money out of the welfare office, but only after a struggle.
it is a struggle (for sb) to do sth
▪ it was a struggle for my mother to understand our lifestyle, but she tried very hard.
it is a struggle doing sth
▪ it was a struggle trying to feed a family of five on my salary.

children.name: be hard put to do sth u
children.definition: be hard put to do sth/ be hard pressed to do sth if you say someone would be hard put or hard pressed to do something, you doubt that they would be able to do it because you think it is too difficult:
examples: ▪ the two girls look so similar that you’d be hard put to tell the difference between them.
▪ the governor will be hard pressed to find more money for schools while dealing with a $6 billion budget deficit.

children.name: have your work cut out x
children.definition: have your work cut out for youalsohave your work cut out/hæv jɔːʳ ˌwɜːʳk kʌt ˈaʊt (fəʳ juː)/  informal to have to work very hard if you are going to succeed in doing something:
examples: nỗ lực để hoàn thành kịp cái gì
▪ i’ll have my work cut out to get this design finished by this afternoon.
tôi sẽ nỗ lực hơn để hoàn thành bản thiết kế trong chiều nay.
▪ rice hopes to break the record during tonight’s game, but he’ll have his work cut out for him.
rice hy vọng mình sẽ phá kỷ lục trong trận đấu tối nay, nhưng anh sẽ phải nỗ lực nhiều.

children.name: be thrown in at the deep end c2
children.definition: be thrown in at the deep end/biː ˌθrəʊn ɪn ət ðə ˈdiːp end/  informal to have to start doing something difficult such as a new job without people making it easier for you because you are new:bị ném vào thử thách
examples: ▪ when i first started teaching i was really thrown in at the deep end -- i had a class of forty six-year-olds all on my own.

children.name: a time when you have a lot of problems
difficult a1
children.definition: difficult/hard/ˈdɪfɪkəlt, hɑːʳd/  use this about a period of time when you have a lot of problems or a lot of bad things happen to you:
examples: khó khăn
▪ the last few months have been especially hard for her.
mấy tháng vừa qua đặc biệt khó khăn với cô ta.
▪ those few days were so difficult that i decided to leave my job.
mấy ngày qua thật khó khăn nên tôi đã quyết định thôi việc.
▪ 1996 was perhaps the worst year the automobile industry has faced so far.
cho đến nay năm 1996 có lẽ là năm tồi tệ nhất mà ngành công nghiệp ô tô phải trải qua.
have a difficult/hard time
có khoảng thời gian khó khăn
▪ most families have a very difficult time dealing with a family member’s drug addiction.
nhiều gia đình có khoảng thời gian khó khăn khi có thành viên trong nhà nghiện ma túy.

children.name: hard b2
children.definition: difficult/hard/ˈdɪfɪkəlt, hɑːʳd/  use this about a period of time when you have a lot of problems or a lot of bad things happen to you:
examples: khó khăn
▪ the last few months have been especially hard for her.
▪ those few days were so difficult that i decided to leave my job.
▪ 1996 was perhaps the worst year the automobile industry has faced so far.
have a difficult/ hard time
▪ most families have a very difficult time dealing with a family member’s drug addiction.

children.name: tough b2
children.definition: toughspokenuse this about a situation or period of time when you have had a lot of problems or a lot of bad things have happened to you:khó khăn
examples: he’s a good person to be with if ever you’re in a tough situation.
many of the veteran players had a tough time adjusting to the coach’s style.

children.name: needing a lot of energy or physical effort
hard b1
children.definition: hard/hɑːʳd/  tiring and needing a lot of work, energy, or physical effort:
examples: khó khăn
▪ let your mother sit down. she’s had a hard day at work.
để mẹ cậu ngồi nghỉ chút đi. bà ấy vừa trải qua một ngày mệt mỏi.
▪ their car broke down, and they were suddenly faced with a long hard walk back to the nearest town.
xe hư, và bỗng dưng họ phải đi một quãng đường dài mệt mỏi đến thị trấn gần nhất.

children.name: strenuous c2
children.definition: strenuous/ˈstrenjuəs/  needing a lot of physical effort:
examples: đòi hỏi nhiều cố gắng, căng thẳng
▪ the doctors advised against any strenuous activity for six weeks.
▪ last season his trainers put him through a strenuous running program.

children.name: backbreaking x
children.definition: backbreaking/ back-breaking/ˈbækbreɪkɪŋ/  backbreaking work, especially work that involves carrying and lifting heavy things, is extremely hard and needs a lot of physical effort:
examples: kiệt sức, vất vả
▪ after four hours of backbreaking work, we had finally pulled the wall down.
sau bốn tiếng làm việc vất vả, chúng tôi cuối cùng cũng kéo được bức tường xuống.

children.name: gruelling x
children.definition: gruellingbritish /gruelingamerican /ˈgruːəlɪŋ/  something that is gruelling is extremely tiring because it continues for a long time and you have to use a lot of effort continuously:
examples: kiệt sức, mệt nhoài
▪ the le mans 24-hour race is the most gruelling event in the motor-racing calendar.
đường đua 24 giờ le mans là sự kiện vất vả nhất trong mùa giải.
▪ before they join the army, young recruits are put through a particularly grueling endurance course.
trước khi gia nhập quân đội, lính mới sẽ trải qua một khóa huấn luyện sức bền chuyên biệt.

children.name: arduous x
children.definition: arduous/ˈɑːʳdjuəsǁ-dʒuəs/  written work or a journey that is arduous is long and tiring and needs a lot of strength and effort:
examples: gian nan
▪ in those days, long-distance travel was slow and arduous.
những ngày này, những chuyến đi xa thường rất chậm và đầy gian nan.
▪ today, corbett will continue his arduous climb to the top of the park’s highest peak.
hôm nay, corbert sẽ tiếp tục cuộc hành trình leo lên điểm cao nhất của khu đất.

children.name: punishing x
children.definition: punishing/ˈpʌnɪʃɪŋ/  extremely difficult in a way that damages or weakens something or makes someone feel very tired:
examples: kiệt sức, nghiêm trọng
▪ the transatlantic flight was a punishing task for the plane’s old engines.
chuyến bay vượt đại tây dương là một nhiệm vụ khó khăn đối với động cơ cũ rích của máy bay.
▪ he set himself a punishing schedule of talks, lectures and conferences all over america.
anh ấy đặt mình vào một lịch trình dày đặc gồm những buổi thuyết trình, bài giảng và hội nghị khắp nước mỹ.

children.name: be murder x
children.definition: be murder/biː ˈmɜːʳdəʳ/  spoken use this when something is extremely difficult and needs a lot of effort or skill:
examples: kiệt sức
▪ traveling five days a week is murder. i can’t do it anymore.
đi năm ngày một tuần thật sự kiệt sức. tôi không đi được nữa đâu.
it is murder doing something
mệt mỏi làm gì đó
▪ it’s murder trying to park in this town!
tìm chỗ đậu xe trong thành phố này thật là mệt mỏi quá đi!

children.name: be a slog x
children.definition: be a slog/biː ə ˈslɒgǁ-ˈslɑːg/  british informal if something is a slog, it takes a lot of time and effort and is often boring:
examples: quá trình vất vả
▪ he didn’t become famous overnight -- it’s been a long hard slog.
▪ the first half of the book was quite interesting but the last part was a bit of a slog.

children.name: sb who is difficult to live, work, deal with
difficult b1
children.definition: difficultsbwho is difficult is not easy to live with or work with because they do not behave in a helpful, friendly way:khó tính, khó chịu, khó khăn
examples: when darren was a little boy, he was very difficult at times.
his wife is a very difficult woman.
please children, don't be so difficult!
difficult to deal/ live/ work/ etc with
the manager is difficult to deal with/a difficult person to deal with.campbell has the reputation of being difficult to work with.

children.name: awkward b2
children.definition: awkward/ˈɔːkwəʳd/  someone who is awkward is deliberately unhelpful and unfriendly, and seems to like causing problems for people:
examples: hay gây phiền hà, quấy nhiễu
▪ do you have to be so awkward about everything?
bạn có cần phải làm mọi thứ rối tung lên như vậy không?

children.name: impossible c2
children.definition: impossible/ɪmˈpɒsɪbəl, ɪmˈpɒsəbəlǁɪmˈpɑː-/ spokensomeone who is impossible makes you annoyed and impatient, for example because they are never satisfied or they keep changing their mind:
examples: quá đáng, quá quắt
▪ she’s impossible! even when i offer to help her she always finds some reason to complain.
cô ta thật quá quắt! thậm chí khi tôi đề nghị giúp đỡ thì cô ta cũng tìm cách phàn nàn cho bằng được.
▪ dan’s impossible to live with when he’s sick.
dan trở nên quá quắt khi bị ốm.

children.name: be a pain b2
children.definition: be a pain (in the neck)/biː ə ˌpeɪn (ɪn ðə ˈnek)/  someone who is a pain is annoying and difficult to deal with:
examples: rắc rối, phiền phức
▪ carla can be a pain sometimes, but she’s been a good friend to me.
carla đôi khi có thể phiền phức, nhưng cô ấy là người bạn tốt.
▪ little brothers are such a pain in the neck!
em trai đúng là phiền phức!

children.name: problem child x
children.definition: problem child/ˈprɒbləm ˌtʃaɪldǁˈprɑː-/  a child who is always behaving badly and often gets into trouble:
examples: đứa trẻ ngỗ nghịch
▪ in my years as a teacher, i’ve seen plenty of problem children come and go.

children.name: not the easiest... u
children.definition: not the easiest... very difficult to deal with, live with, work with etc:
examples: ▪ i’m not surprised you’ve had problems with diane. she’s not the easiest person to work with, is she?

children.name: bolshie x
children.definition: bolshy/bolshie british informalsbwho is bolshy behaves in an unhelpful, bad-tempered way and argues with the people that they are supposed to obey:thiếu thiện chí, bướng bỉnh
examples: stop being so bolshie and just get on with it, will you?

children.name: difficult a1
children.definition: difficult/ˈdɪfɪkəlt/  difficult conditions are ones that make what you are doing more difficult:khókhăn
examples: heavy snow will mean difficult driving conditions in some areas.
i’d like to thank the staff for working very hard in these difficult conditions.

children.name: unfavourable c2
children.definition: unfavourablebritish /unfavorableamerican  unfavourable conditions make it difficult for sb to do sth, or for sth to exist:bất lợi
examples: bloom states clearly that he believes that many schools provide unfavorable learning conditions.
despite an unfavourable business environment, the stock market remained steady.
unfavourable for
weather forecasters said winds and 13-foot waves may make conditions unfavorable for clean-up and salvage operations.

children.name: adverse c2
children.definition: adverse
examples: 1not good or favourable : khắt khe
they fear it could have anadverse effecton global financial markets.
miller’s campaign has received a good deal ofadverse publicity.
in spite of adverse public opinion, the plan to privatize the railways continued.
2 adverse conditionsconditions that make it difficult for something to happen or exist : khắc nghiệt
the expedition was abandoned because of adverse weather conditions.
planes are being kept on the ground because of the adverse weather.

children.name: troubled c1
children.definition: troubledadjectivehaving difficulties
examples: 1. having problems or difficulties
the survival package involves selling off the unprofitable parts of the troubledcompany.
this troubledregionhas had more than its fair share of wars over the the centuries.
in these troubledtimes, it makes a change to hear some good news.

children.name: be in for sth c2
children.definition: be in forsthphrasal verb
examples: to be going to experience something unpleasant very soon
the weather forecast says we're in for heavy rain this evening.
you'll be in forit(= she will be very angry) if you don't do what she tells you.

children.name: ambitious b2
children.definition: ambitiousadjective
examples: 2. if a plan or idea is ambitious, it needs a great amount of skill and effort to be successful or be achieved
she has some ambitious expansionplansfor her business.
the government has announced an ambitious programme to modernize the railway network.
the original completion date wasover-ambitious, so we have had to delay the opening by six months.

children.name: severely b2
children.definition: severelyadverbvery seriously
examples: 1. very seriously
their daughter was severely injured in a car accident.
severely disabled/handicapped
job opportunities are severely limited/restricted at the moment.

children.name: formidable c2
